Award.AwardTitle: Conference: Baltimore Earth Stewardship Initiative Demonstration Project, Baltimore, MD; August 9 - 14, 2015
Award.AbstractNarration:
Urban environments are designed by people for people. The ecological consequences of this design in terms of human health and well being are large. How can ecological knowledge best inform urban design? This demonstration project, which is part of the Earth Stewardship Initiative, will bring together city managers, landscape designers, community leaders, and ecologists to envision the future of Baltimore's people and neighborhoods. Promoting a new role for ecologists in shaping urban design will require negotiating new collaborations that will be demonstrated during the 2015 annual meeting of the Ecological Society of America, which will be held in Baltimore. Graduate research fellows, landscape architects, Baltimore city officials, research ecologists, architecture studios, high school students, and community members will participate equally in the demonstration. Projects developed collaboratively during the August meeting will be further developed through a graduate course offered through Yale University?s joint program in Environmental Studies and Architecture. The initiative has garnered support across the Ecological Society of American from its sections on applied ecology, human ecology, environmental justice, education, natural history, agroecology, and Asian ecology.

This year's Earth Stewardship Demonstration initiative will link community perspectives on neighborhoods, green space, and environmental stewardship with urban ecological researchers interested in studying and shaping urban environments and strengthening communities. Teams will extend 3 nascent Baltimore revitalization projects through a series of steps that bring together ecological research experiments with community planning and urban ecosystems functioning. Landscape Architecture Studios at the University of Virginia, Pennsylvania State University, and the University of Maryland have investigated these sites through the design process and generated materials on each of them. Graduate research fellows will serve as core investigators and organizers with ecology and design advisors. Six project themes inform the projects that will be developed: Public Health, Access and Recreation; Degraded Soils and Land; Landscape Performance, Education and Maintenance; Watersheds and Aquatic Habitats; Biodiversity and Managed Populations; and Climate Change Adaptation. The demonstration projects will be implemented through diverse activities, including visits to revitalization sites in Baltimore, an urban bioblitz, special and organized presentation sessions, a community workshop, a landscape architecture foundation workshop, design charrettes, and an open town hall meeting. Graduate student leaders will develop a project for each of the three sites that will be further developed in a fall course.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sustainability goals will be met only if we change the way science intersects society. Working with the Ecological Society of America (ESA) along with multiple organizations in Baltimore over the summer we have developed a large-scale Earth Stewardship Initiative (ESI), connecting communities with ecologists, urban planners, and designers, including students. The initiative proposes co-design and co-management of urban environments to promote social and ecological resilience and health.  

The Baltimore ESI seeks to integrate community perspectives on neighborhoods, green space, and environmental stewardship with socio-ecological research and planning. Important outcomes of this project include: (1) a means to expand research options and generate new knowledge about urban ecosystems; (2) a forum for prioritizing ecology within the context of real world projects, that repositions ecological science as a critical component of urban design and thus as an idealized version and vision for the future; (3) a demonstration project at the ESA conference linking ecological researchers with designers to develop designed experiments on three active community-driven planning projects; (4) an establisment of priority sites for fostering partnerships and transdisciplinary collaboration between ecological researchers, city officials and communities that builds on the Baltimore Ecosystem Study and partnerships with the Parks & People Foundation and local professional organizations; (5) Multi-level participation and cross level exchanges (phd, early career, senior researchers across a range of education programs linking communities to young ecologists and designers; (6) a pedagogy to teach applied urban ecology through real-world training; (8) a way of building team science by “jumping into the deep end”; (9)  a means of digesting critical ecological information and making it interpretable to a lay audience with science perspectives aligned with other critical project drivers; (10) A means to position ecologists in the role of shaping communities through agency, civic ecology and action science on real world projects.

Teams worked on three ongoing revitalization projects at ecologically and socially diverse sites in the city of Baltimore; Harlem Park Inner Block parks, Patterson Park, and the Middle Branch. Site visits and dialogue with community leaders, city officials, and professionals from Baltimore were arranged. Graduate research fellows served as core investigators and organizers and worked with ecology and design advisors on project deliverables for each site.  The week included an Urban Bioblitz, Special Session, Ignite Session, and Organized Oral sessions, a community workshop, Landscape Architecture Foundation workshop, and design charettes as well as a Town Hall meeting to hear final presentations and discuss next steps.

The ESI team incorporated Designed Experiments into planning projects as a framework to bridge ecology with landscape architecture and inform urban and landscape design decisions and management for community benefit.  Designed Experiments embed experiments within design projects and methodically integrate scientific analysis into urban planning, design, and engineered ecosystems. The design process brings ecologists, designers, and engineers together with stakeholders and communities and fosters trans- and interdisciplinary collaboration.  It combines bottom-up community engagement and field research with top-down site planning, interagency dialogue, and creative design solutions. Community participation in workshops prior to and during the conference will ensure the social, cultural, and public health needs will be integrated into the design and research frameworks at these land sites.

Working with ESA leadership we are also building on activities shared across several sections and chapters of the ESA, with financial support from Applied Ecology, Human Ecology, Environmental Justice, Education, Natural History, Agroecology, Asian Ecology, and the Student Chapter. Initial funding has been provided through Yale University and the ESA to establish the project during the ESA conference.  These funds have supported the team in the development of the projects. In addition, prior work and collaborations leading up to this summer include spring 2015 Landscape Architecture Studios at the University of Virginia, Penn State, and the University of Maryland to investigate three of the sites through the design process and to generate project materials focusing on each of them, with an additional studio from a prior year used on the fourth site. Mahan Rykiel developed the Experimental Design Initiative, focusing on schools and education in Baltimore.  Biohabitats is involved in planning a project and coordinating the Bioblitz for ESA.

The event included the following number of participants throughout the week:

•   18 ESI Research Fellow and Research Assistants;

•   12 ESI Design Fellows;

•   11 Baltimore city officials;

•   8 Advisory Team ESA Ecologists and BES Researchers;

•   6  Advisory Team Designer and landscape Architects;

•   4 different landscape architecture studios across universities;

•   5 local high school students;

•   Roughlty 65 Community members;

•   Prime exposure during the ESA conference with an estimated 5,000 attendants.

After the conference, a fall course was taught to refine proposals at Yale University entitled: Ecological Urban Planning. It is situated between Yale University’s school of Forestry and Environmental Studies and the School of Architecture.
